awd_titl_txt: CEDAR: The Coupled OH Meinel and O2 Atmospheric Band Nightglow Emissions
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to SRI International (Dr. Konstantinos Kalogerakis) will support the quantitative reevaluation of the mesosphere and lower thermosphere chemistry based upon new laboratory results.  Nightglow emission signatures observed from space and ground-based instruments are commonly used as proxies for atmospheric composition, especially for the altitude region around 100 km that cannot be easily studied in situ. Monitoring the intensity and temporal evolution of such proxies by remote sensing is the method of choice to study many phenomena occurring in this region of the atmosphere. This award would support the quantitative reanalysis of the details relevant to the production and loss of excited atomic and molecular precursors responsible for prominent nightglow emissions. These results would quantify more precisely the study of atmospheric composition, radiative and energy balance, wave propagation and dissipation, as well as transport dynamics. One or two undergraduate students would be engaged in this work through a site REU grant awarded to SRI International.

The thrust of this reevaluation to be supported by this award would be aimed at the investigation of the coupling between the OH Meinel and the O2 Atmospheric band emissions, which is connected to the collisions of O atoms with vibrationally excited OH. Part of this study would utilize observational data sets derived from multiple sounding rocket experiments that would be combined with modeling methodologies based upon recently developed efforts based upon new laboratory findings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Layers of glimmering light commonly known as airglow encapsulate Earth's atmosphere near the edge of space. These layers are usually too faint to be seen by the naked eye from the ground at night, but are constantly present in the region where Earth's atmosphere meets space. Airglow during the night, commonly referred to as nightglow, represents an important target for remote-sensing observations by space- and ground-based instruments. This phenomenon is the manifestation of important atmospheric processes and encodes information on atmospheric composition and dynamics.

This project investigated key mesospheric nightglow emissions with emphasis on the recently established connection between the OH Meinel and the O2 Atmospheric band emissions, mediated by collisions of O atoms with the highly vibrationally excited hydroxyl radical, OH(high v). Analysis of several extant data sets obtained during sounding rocket experiments considered OH(v) + O collisions as a source of the O2 Atmospheric band emission. Inclusion of our recent laboratory results in a model for multi-quantum vibrational relaxation of OH(v = 5-9) + O, leading to O(1D) generation and subsequent energy transfer to oxygen to generate the O2 Atmospheric band emission, indicated that this pathway exceeds production by O-atom tertiary association, O + O + M, especially for cases when there was extensive overlap between the OH and O-atom layers. Analysis of the atomic oxygen green line emission observed by sounding rockets enabled the comparison of observations between coincident measurements by different satellite instruments. In addition, analysis of high-resolution sky spectra obtained by astronomical telescopes explored the temporal evolution of the nightglow emissions mentioned above. Finally, analysis of observations of the ionospheric atomic oxygen red line emission near 630 nm from extant artificial aurora experiments (also known as ionospheric heating) addressed unacceptably large, long-standing discrepancies between observed and calculated lifetimes. This analysis confirmed the crucial role of O atoms in the deactivation of excited O(1D) atoms and provided evidence for the important role of the process of dissociative recombination of the molecular oxygen cation, O2+ as a source of O(1D) influencing the observed lifetimes in these types of experiments, especially for altitudes below approximately 250 km.

Results were disseminated via scientific conferences and other outreach activities. The project contributed to a peer-reviewed conference proceedings paper. Two additional manuscripts are in preparation as of the project expiration date. The project also contributed to the design of a future sounding rocket campaign as part of an international collaboration.

This NSF project provided support for two research scientists and research training for two summer undergraduate students, who participated in an NSF-funded Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU-Physics) program.
